PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
1.  The project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) will review the key issues and 
constraints  identified  in  the  problem  tree  analysis  and  verify  if  the  outcome  and  outputs 
proposed in the preliminary design and monitoring framework are effective to achieve the 
expected impact. Participation and ownership by the Government and local organizations are 
essential  for  the  successful  results  of  the  Program  and  the  PPTA  will  conduct  intensive 
dialogues and discussions for consensus building among the stakeholders. The PPTA will also 
conduct  due  diligence  and  safeguard  reviews  and  develop  further  details  of  the  Program 
(procurement plan, cost estimates, implementation schedule, etc.). 
 
B.  Major Outputs and Activities

through  desk  reviews,  focused  interviews,  surveys,  participatory  discussions.  The  Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  will  provide  frequent  monitoring  and  guidance  for  the  PPTA 
consultants.

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement  
3.  The  technical  assistance  (TA)  is  estimated  to  cost  $700,000  equivalent,  of  which 
$600,000.00 equivalent will be financed on a grant basis from the Japan Fund for Poverty 
Reduction, and administrated by ADB. The Government will finance the remaining $100,000 
equivalent.  The  Government's  financing  include  counterpart  staff  support,  office  space, 
transport, and utilities, mostly in kind. The detailed cost estimate is presented in Table A5.2.

5.  The outline terms of references for the project preparatory TA consultants are described 
below:  
 
(i)  Microfinance  Institution  Development  Specialist/Team  Leader 
(international, 6 person-months). 
  Supervise and coordinate the work of other consultant team members, ensure 
their quality outputs, and timely submission to ADB. 
  Conduct policy dialogues, focused discussions, and workshops with relevant 
organizations for consensus building. 
  Conduct a diagnostic review of the microfinance sector policy. 
  Guide and monitor the microfinance mapping and baseline survey. 
  Assess the training need of microfinance institutions (MFIs) in Nepal, and 
develop a plan to establish a training facility/institute dedicated to MFIs.  
  Develop  an  appropriate  operational  modality  for  microfinance  outreach 
expansion in hills and mountains in line with ADB’s requirements of financial 
intermediary loans.

16  Appendix 5 
  Develop a plan to establish a MFI management information system support 
window.  
  Develop  a  plan  to  strengthen  microfinance  wholesale  organization  for 
expanded outreach.  
  Assist ADB missions. 
 
(ii)  Microfinance Regulation Specialist (international, 2 person-months).  
  Review the existing legal and regulatory framework for microfinance including 
a  Draft  Micro  Finance  Act.  In  consultation  with  the  sector  stakeholders, 
develop  recommendations  in  view  of  establishing  the  sound  microfinance 
sector. 
  Develop a business and operation plan for the second tier institution (STI). 
  Develop an information technology infrastructure plan for the STI and draft a 
necessary procurement plan. 
  Develop prudential norms, information and disclosure system, accounting, 
auditing and licensing procedures for MFIs for self-regulation. 
 
(iii)  Microfinance MIS Development Specialist (international, 2 person-months).  
  Develop a plan for a management information system (MIS) development 
fund to provide financial and technical support to develop MIS at MFIs based 
on a matching grant. 
  Asses the potential of technology based MF products such as a debit card, 
ATM, and mobile based microfinance services and develop a proposal on 
pilot scheme of such products. The proposal shall be detailed in implementing 
modalities, resource requirements, follow-up and continuation plan. 
  Assess the potential of extending formal remittance services in rural areas by 
linking formal remittance providers (banks) to MFIs by introducing point of 
sale and debit card system to MFIs and develop a plan for such pilot scheme. 
 
(iv)  Economic  and  financial  analysis  specialist  (international,  2  person-
months).   
  Conduct economic and financial analysis. 
  Develop financial and cost estimates. 
  Assist ADB missions to develop a procurement plan. 
 
(v)  Microfinance Development Specialist (national, 6 person-months).  
  Assist the international consultant team leader. 
  Review the overall PPTA outputs for quality enhancement. 
  In support of the consultant team leader, conduct stakeholders discussions 
and disseminations. 
  Assist the consultant team leader in information and data collection. 
 
(vi)  Gender and Social Development Specialist (national, 2 person-months). 
  Assess the capacity of the proposed executing and implementing agencies to 
deliver gender sensitive microfinance services. 
  Conduct gender and social analysis and develop poverty reduction strategy.  
  Develop a gender action plan. 
  Assess the presence and situation of indigenous peoples in the program 
areas and estimated program benefits to those people. 
  Develop gender related monitoring indicators.

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
6.  The executing agency of the PPTA is the Ministry of Finance (MOF), the Government of 
Nepal. MOF will form and chair a TA steering committee comprising representatives from MOF, 
the Nepal Rastra Bank (NRB)/the central bank, and the Rural Microfinance Development Centre 
(RMDC),  the  microfinance  wholesale  organization.  The  TA  steering  committee,  through  its 
chairperson  designate,  will  be  responsible  for  overall  implementation.  NRB  will  be  the 
implementing agency and will implement and coordinate the PPTA activities on behalf of MOF. 
NRB, in coordination with MOF, will provide office space, one counterpart staff, and support 
services by its staff.
